The now-defunct Alexander Strategy Group was a lobbying shop that worked closely with superlobbyist Jack Abramoff, former Rep. Randy 'Duke' Cunningham, R-Calif., and former Republican House majority leader Tom DeLay - all convicted criminals for various levels of corruption.

The site of Eshkol Academy, a defunct Orthodox Jewish boys day school founded by superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff in 2002. The school was largely funded by laundered money through Abramoff's Capital Athletic Foundation.

Americans for Tax Reform was one of the non-profits implicated in the Jack Abramoff scandal in 2006. They alledgedly laundered funds from Abramoff clients in exchange for favorable publicity and connections with high level officials, including then-President George W. Bush.

Former Rep. William J. Jefferson, D-La., stuffed cash for bribes in the freezer of his Washington DC home. He is now serving the longest sentence ever given to a member of Congress.

On June 17, 1972 five men were arrested after infiltrating the 6th floor headquarters of the Democratic National Committee at the Watergate complex. The details of the professional break-in eventually uncovered connections to the highest levels of Richard Nixon's administration, leading to the only resignation of a US President in history.

In 1972 this address served as the headquarters for the Committee to Re-elect the President, a fundraising organization for President Richard Nixon that played an active role in the Watergate scandal. CRP (also known as CREEP) paid the legal expenses of the Watergate burglars in exchange for their silence, which included a member of their payroll and eventually led to the unraveling of the scandal that ended with Nixon's resignation.
Place: Offices of the Committee to Re-elect the President

Draft of Tip: In 1972, Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward met with former FBI official Mark Felt (also known as 'Deep Throat') in parking space 34D on the bottom level of this parking garage. Felt provided key information to the Washington Post that eventually led to the resignation of President Nixon.
Place: Meeting place of Bob Woodward and Deep Throat/Mark Felt
Address: Parking space 34D, 1401 Wilson Blvd Arlington, VA 22209

Draft of Tip: In 1972 apartment 617 belonged to Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward and if his contact Mark Felt (also known as 'Deep Throat') wanted to meet, he would mark Woodward's morning paper with a code indicating a meeting time.
